translated: Catalog of the Requested Works of the Great Master Chizhao
In the Tang Dynasty, in the Tangxing County of Tiantai Mountain, Guoqing Temple in the Dongdao of Zhejiang Province.

The monk Enchin of the Tendai Temple on Mount Hiei in Japan, on a pilgrimage to the two capitals, two Zhejiang provinces, Lingnan, Fujian province, and other places, compiled a general catalog of his studies.
He obtained the sutras, vinaya, treatises, and biographies of the Mahayana and Hinayana teachings.
As well as the great dhÄraá¹‡Ä« teachings and maá¹‡á¸ala diagrams.
The Tiantai perfect and sudden teachings.
And various commentaries, sub-commentaries, and miscellaneous sutras and treatises in Sanskrit.
From beginning to end, a total of 441 works in 1,000 fascicles.
Ritual implements and Dharma objects, etc.
A total of 16 items.

All miscellaneous sections.
The sections are incomplete.
Or there were old texts.
Therefore, they are compiled as miscellaneous and not included at the beginning.

One large box of Sanskrit scriptures from the great NÄlandÄ Monastery in Central India, one box of palm leaf Sanskrit scriptures from the Buddha hall in front of the great NÄlandÄ Monastery, one mature copper five-pronged small vajra with a ring on the right - these three items.
All of these were brought from the Buddha's country in the West to the Great Tang by the brÄhmaá¹‡a Tripiá¹­aka.
His journey took 168,000 li.
The hardships are difficult to describe.
When Enchin just arrived in Fuzhou,
he met the Tripiá¹­aka master.
He received the Siddham chapter,
and was also entrusted with three kinds of Dharma faith.
It is to be transmitted to the home country,
and permanently used for offerings.
Those who see, hear, rejoice, and wish will certainly have the same karmic affinity.
One pillar staff made of betel nut tree from India, one pillar staff made of ban grass from Guangzhou, one glass bottle - these three items.
This is the Japanese monk Tendaien Enkaku.
He came over in the fifth year of Kaiyuan and stayed at Wutai for a long time.
Later he traveled to Chang'an.
We met in the city in the ninth year of the Dazhong era.
We worked together to copy scriptures and draw maá¹‡á¸alas. In the sixth month of the tenth year, we saw Yuanzhen off and accompanied him to Tiantai.
He stayed for the remaining summer.
In the autumn moon, we went out on a tour and arrived in Guangzhou.
We met merchants from our homeland, including Li Yingjue and Chen Taixin.
They sent the aforementioned gifts.
We will now permanently offer them to our homeland.
One horsetail whisk, one walking stick made of a Nanhai rattan tree - these two items.
These were sent by Chan Master Zunshi, the Great Virtuous Monk who Transmits the Teachings at Kaiyuan Temple in Fuzhou, to Yuanzhen as a Dharma gift.
The above six items.
All are Dharma objects and equipment.

A Catalogue of the Dharma Transmitted by the Monk Enchin of Japan, in One Scroll. A General Catalogue of the Dharma Sought in Tang China by the Monk Enchin of Japan's Capital's Enryakuji Temple on Mount Hiei, in One Scroll. The above includes the teachings of the Kaiyuan and Zhenyuan eras, as well as commentaries, records, collections, diagrams, images, ritual implements, and dharma objects of the two Southern and Northern Schools, along with catalogues from before and after, each itemized in detail as above.
May it be widely transmitted in the ten directions, thoroughly conveying the Buddha's intent.
Respectfully, this merit is dedicated to the myriad vehicles above.
Below, it rescues the myriad people.
Standing, it reaches the three realms.
Spreading out, it spans a thousand lands.
Faith and slander both form the causes for perfect enlightenment.
Enemies and loved ones equally ride the vast vehicle.
One reaches the ultimate position of the Great Sun.
Respectfully recorded.

Recorded by the monk Enchin of Enryakuji Temple in the capital of Japan on the fifteenth day of the fifth month in the twelfth year of the Dajing era of the Great Tang Dynasty. Translation: Translation: A Catalog of Sought-after Dharma, in one fascicle, respectfully sent to the Great Minister of the Right. Respectfully received the connection.
Recorded by the monk Enchin on the eighteenth day of the fourth month in the third year of Tian'an in Japan, the year jiamao.
